snippet: Beate Zschäpe, in a statement to a Munich court, rejected charges she had been part of an underground cell that killed nine immigrants and a policewoman from 2000 to 2007.
abstract: Beate Zschape's lawyer reads 53-page statement in German court, first time Zschape has broken her silence about involvement with neo-Nazi group National Socialist Underground, which was accused of killing nine immigrants and policewoman from 2000 to 2007; Zschape admits to being guilty of failing to prevent crimes carried out by group but denies any part in murders.

byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy contributed reporting from Paris.

lead_paragraph: Beate Zschäpe, in a statement to a Munich court, rejected charges she had been part of an underground cell that killed nine immigrants and a policewoman from 2000 to 2007.

headline.main: German Woman Denies Role in Murders in Neo-Nazi Case
headline.print_headline: Suspect in Neo-Nazi Trial Ends Her 2-Year Silence
